newsitem.title: BRAZIL: FOCUS-Brazil bond swap helps shed debtor stigma.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Brazil bond swap helps shed debtor stigma.

text.p: Brazil took a big step toward freeing itself from the stigma of Latin America's 1980s debt crisis Wednesday when investors agreed to swap the nation's restructured U.S.-backed bonds for new uncollateralized bonds.
"We became more friendly to big institutional savers as we restructured away from rescheduled debt," said Gustavo Franco, Brazilian Central Bank director for international affairs.
"It is always good to retire restructured debt," Franco told reporters in New York following the retirement of some $2.72 billion in Brady bonds in a swap for 30-year uncollateralized bonds.
Brady bonds, named after former U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, have been issued by emerging market nations to restructure commercial bank debt of the 1980s.
Brazil, along with Mexico and Argentina, led the pack of Latin American debtors that emerged from default status through the issue of Brady bonds since 1990.
Wednesday's bond exchange essentially asked investors to give up their U.S. Treasury-backed Brady bonds for higher yielding bonds backed solely by the credit-worthiness of the Brazilian government.
Brazilian officials cheered the deal, saying it showed global investors were confident Brazil could stand behind its own long-term paper.
It also follows a credit upgrade earlier in the year by U.S. rating agency Standard & Poor's Corp to BB-minus from B-plus, a move Brazilian officials said was long overdue.

The bond swap retired only $2.71 billion of the nation's total $44 billion in Brady debt. But more important, analysts said, was the fact that investors jumped at the opportunity to buy long-term uncollateralized bonds from Brazil.
"The major benefit was probably to define a long-dated benchmark for Brazil," said Kurt Schmid, head of proprietary trading at SBC Warburg in New York.
The newly issued uncollateralized bond totaled $3.0 billion, the second largest 30-year bond in the market after Italy's $3.5 billion issue, according to Brazil's Central Bank.
Mexico carried out a similar Brady bond swap last year, but managed to sell only about $1.7 billion in new bonds.

"We had over $16 billion in cash offers for the 30-year bond, which shows how interested investors were in the issue," said Linaldo Aguiar, head of the Brazilian Central Bank's foreign debt department.
Still, the deal was seen as the first step in a long-term plan to retire the collateralized debt.
"This demand signals that there is further potential (for a swap), but that doesn't mean we would want to do something tomorrow," Aguiar said.
